status.summary: Timeouts in mozilla::layers::LockD3DTexture<T>

Kelsey.author: sotaro.ikeda.g@gmail.com
Kelsey.text:
Each D3D11TextureData::Lock() acquires exclusive access by using IDXGIKeyedMutex::AcquireSync(0, 10000) in LockD3DTexture(). And each D3D11TextureData::Unlock() releases exclusive access by using IDXGIKeyedMutex::ReleaseSync(0) in UnlockD3DTexture().

From crash reports, crashes seemed to be triggered by IDXGIKeyedMutex::AcquireSync() failure in D3D11TextureData::Lock().

When using ID3D11Fence, ID3D11Fence is generated from the same ID3D11Device as D3D11TextureData::mTexture in DeviceManagerDx::GetCanvasDevice(). Each D3D11TextureData::Lock() does not need to wait Fence since ID3D11Fence creating device and signaling device is same. Each D3D11TextureData::Unlock() need to increment fence value and signal fence by using ID3D11DeviceContext4::Signal().

- https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/d3d11_3/nf-d3d11_3-id3d11devicecontext4-signal

By using ID3D11Fence, D3D11TextureData::Lock() does not need to wait in CanvasTranslator use case.

Sotaro.author: sotaro.ikeda.g@gmail.com
Sotaro.text:
Each D3D11TextureData::Lock() acquires exclusive access by using IDXGIKeyedMutex::AcquireSync(0, 10000) in LockD3DTexture(). And each D3D11TextureData::Unlock() releases exclusive access by using IDXGIKeyedMutex::ReleaseSync(0) in UnlockD3DTexture().

From crash reports, crashes seemed to be triggered by IDXGIKeyedMutex::AcquireSync() failure in D3D11TextureData::Lock().

When using ID3D11Fence, ID3D11Fence is generated from the same ID3D11Device as D3D11TextureData::mTexture in DeviceManagerDx::GetCanvasDevice(). Each D3D11TextureData::Lock() does not need to wait Fence since ID3D11Fence creating device and signaling device is same. Each D3D11TextureData::Unlock() need to increment fence value and signal fence by using ID3D11DeviceContext4::Signal().

- https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/d3d11_3/nf-d3d11_3-id3d11devicecontext4-signal

By using ID3D11Fence, D3D11TextureData::Lock() does not need to wait in CanvasTranslator use case.

status.summary: YouTube videos all green with hardware accel enabled in FF 120

Sotaro.text:
FYI: FF 120.0 braught me a new option regarding NV12: gfx.video.convert-yuv-to-nv12.image-host-win. When I set this to false, then the videos are played without the green screen. 

So again: The following setting heals it on Windows with FF 120.0 for me: gfx.video.convert-yuv-to-nv12.image-host-win=false

I also tried FF 120.0 with the following settings, but they have no effect on getting the green screen for any YouTube video:
layers.iosurfaceimage.use-nv12=false
media.wmf.use-nv12-format=false
media.wmf.zero-copy-nv12-textures=false

Perhaps interesting: On Linux Mint 20.3 (same computer), FF 120 does not show me the green screen. YouTube videos are played normally there. Perhaps NV12 is not supported on Linux? Or at least not with my graphic card driver?
Sotaro.author: urbi1464@gmail.com
release-mgmt-account-bot@mozilla.tld
Sotaro.text:
The bug is marked as tracked for firefox121 (beta). However, the bug still isn't assigned.

:bhood, could you please find an assignee for this tracked bug? Given that it is a regression and we know the cause, we could also simply backout the regressor. If you disagree with the tracking decision, please talk with the release managers.

For more information, please visit [BugBot documentation](https://wiki.mozilla.org/BugBot#tracked_attention.py).

Sotaro.author: ryanvm@gmail.com
Sotaro.text:
Alright, to summarize:
* This was originally caused by bug 1857385, which set the `gfx.video.convert-yuv-to-nv12.image-host-win` preference to `true` for Release builds.
* We reverted bug 1857385 from the Release branch and are building a 120.0.1 dot release later today with that revert included and are aiming to ship it tomorrow if all goes well.
* Bug 1865426 landed on Nightly during the Fx122 cycle to resolve a different issue but also fixed this one as a side effect.
* Bug 1865426 has been backported to the Beta branch for 121.0b6 building Friday. This also includes DevEdition.

Based on all of the above, I'm resolving this bug as fixed for 121 and later by bug 1865426 and fixed by backout for Fx120. The bullet points above cover when users should see the fix arrive on their respective channels.

Is it possible to provide a more reduced testcase?
Erich.author: tnikkel@gmail.com
tnikkel@gmail.com
Erich.text:
(In reply to Erich Gubler [:ErichDonGubler] from comment #6)
> Does setting `webgl.gl_khr_no_error` fix this issue?

Yes it does.
Testing on macos, setting webgl.gl_khr_no_error to the same value as Windows does not reproduce the bug. So maybe it's something related to angle.
Erich.author: tnikkel@gmail.com

Erich.text:
Testing on Windows or mac when webgl.gl_khr_no_error=true in a debug build we actually hit a fatal assert.

[gl:0x14bb7f100] void mozilla::gl::GLContext::raw_fBlitFramebuffer(GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLbitfield, GLenum): Generated unexpected GL_INVALID_OPERATION error.
Crash Annotation GraphicsCriticalError: |[0][GFX1]: void mozilla::gl::GLContext::raw_fBlitFramebuffer(GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLbitfield, GLenum): Generated unexpected GL_INVALID_OPERATION error (t=17.6361) [GFX1]: void mozilla::gl::GLContext::raw_fBlitFramebuffer(GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLbitfield, GLenum): Generated unexpected GL_INVALID_OPERATION error
 
We are passing
0 0 2560 1508 0 0 2560 1508 16384 9728
to BlitFramebuffer so
mask=16384=0x4000=LOCAL_GL_COLOR_BUFFER_BIT
filter=9728=0x2600=LOCAL_GL_NEAREST

https://registry.khronos.org/OpenGL-Refpages/gl4/html/glBlitFramebuffer.xhtml gives reasons why we might get GL_INVALID_OPERATION with a glBlitFramebuffer call. So perhaps the testcase could be doing something not quite correct?

status.summary: Page rendering artifacts on particular Shadertoy example (WR TDR behavior could be better)

JimB.author: jimb@mozilla.com
JimB.text: This looks like the WebGL usage is somehow impacting other parts of Firefox's rendering, so I think this is pretty serious.

JimB.author: ahale@mozilla.com
JimB.text: I'll attempt repro on my nvidia windows 10 system and see if I can characterize this more exactly.

JimB.author: gwatson@mozilla.com
JimB.text: Could you try enable `gfx.webrender.debug.picture-caching` in `about:config`, and capture a screenshot with that enabled when the artifacts occur? It would be interesting to see if the picture cache tile boundaries align with the artifacts.

JimB.author: jgilbert@mozilla.com
JimB.text: This is probably webgl causing a TDR (~timed-out device reset) where the webrender context resets in the middle of a wr rendering, but with default GL state, and so starts drawing into FB0 and such things. Not great but not terrible. No real path to exploit, but it'd be nice for WR to be better-behaved in this case.

I can't repro this on the following computers:
* Ryzen 7 5800X + Geforce RTX 3080 Ti
  * Windows 11
  * Windows 10 (same machine, dual boot for testing)
* Ryzen 9 7950X3D + Radeon RX 7900 XTX on Windows 11
* Dell laptop with Core i9-11900H
  * using Intel UHD Graphics on Windows 11
  * NVIDIA RTX 3050 Ti Laptop GPU on Windows 11 (same machine, device enabled and graphics preference set to high performance for Firefox.exe)
* MSI gaming laptop with Core i7-8750H CPU
  * using Intel UHD Graphics 630 on Windows 11
  * using RTX 2060 Ti laptop GPU (this model is approximately desktop equivalent unlike most laptop GPUs, )

In all cases the display is stable, no artifacting outside the shadertoy view, fans run loudly though on all of these.

I tried with and without vsync on a few of these configurations.

I agree with Kelsey's assessment that this is a TDR, and hence a hardware problem (most commonly either thermal or power related, can be a problem just with that board too).
JimB.author: ahale@mozilla.com

Glenn.author: gwatson@mozilla.com
Glenn.text: Could you try enable `gfx.webrender.debug.picture-caching` in `about:config`, and capture a screenshot with that enabled when the artifacts occur? It would be interesting to see if the picture cache tile boundaries align with the artifacts.

Kelsey.author: sotaro.ikeda.g@gmail.com
Kelsey.text:
Each D3D11TextureData::Lock() acquires exclusive access by using IDXGIKeyedMutex::AcquireSync(0, 10000) in LockD3DTexture(). And each D3D11TextureData::Unlock() releases exclusive access by using IDXGIKeyedMutex::ReleaseSync(0) in UnlockD3DTexture().

From crash reports, crashes seemed to be triggered by IDXGIKeyedMutex::AcquireSync() failure in D3D11TextureData::Lock().

When using ID3D11Fence, ID3D11Fence is generated from the same ID3D11Device as D3D11TextureData::mTexture in DeviceManagerDx::GetCanvasDevice(). Each D3D11TextureData::Lock() does not need to wait Fence since ID3D11Fence creating device and signaling device is same. Each D3D11TextureData::Unlock() need to increment fence value and signal fence by using ID3D11DeviceContext4::Signal().

- https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/d3d11_3/nf-d3d11_3-id3d11devicecontext4-signal

By using ID3D11Fence, D3D11TextureData::Lock() does not need to wait in CanvasTranslator use case.

status.summary: Page rendering artifacts on particular Shadertoy example (WR TDR behavior could be better)

JimB.author: jimb@mozilla.com
JimB.text: This looks like the WebGL usage is somehow impacting other parts of Firefox's rendering, so I think this is pretty serious.

JimB.author: ahale@mozilla.com
JimB.text: I'll attempt repro on my nvidia windows 10 system and see if I can characterize this more exactly.

JimB.author: gwatson@mozilla.com
JimB.text: Could you try enable `gfx.webrender.debug.picture-caching` in `about:config`, and capture a screenshot with that enabled when the artifacts occur? It would be interesting to see if the picture cache tile boundaries align with the artifacts.

JimB.author: jgilbert@mozilla.com
JimB.text: This is probably webgl causing a TDR (~timed-out device reset) where the webrender context resets in the middle of a wr rendering, but with default GL state, and so starts drawing into FB0 and such things. Not great but not terrible. No real path to exploit, but it'd be nice for WR to be better-behaved in this case.

I can't repro this on the following computers:
* Ryzen 7 5800X + Geforce RTX 3080 Ti
  * Windows 11
  * Windows 10 (same machine, dual boot for testing)
* Ryzen 9 7950X3D + Radeon RX 7900 XTX on Windows 11
* Dell laptop with Core i9-11900H
  * using Intel UHD Graphics on Windows 11
  * NVIDIA RTX 3050 Ti Laptop GPU on Windows 11 (same machine, device enabled and graphics preference set to high performance for Firefox.exe)
* MSI gaming laptop with Core i7-8750H CPU
  * using Intel UHD Graphics 630 on Windows 11
  * using RTX 2060 Ti laptop GPU (this model is approximately desktop equivalent unlike most laptop GPUs, )

In all cases the display is stable, no artifacting outside the shadertoy view, fans run loudly though on all of these.

I tried with and without vsync on a few of these configurations.

I agree with Kelsey's assessment that this is a TDR, and hence a hardware problem (most commonly either thermal or power related, can be a problem just with that board too).
JimB.author: ahale@mozilla.com

Glenn.author: gwatson@mozilla.com
Glenn.text: Could you try enable `gfx.webrender.debug.picture-caching` in `about:config`, and capture a screenshot with that enabled when the artifacts occur? It would be interesting to see if the picture cache tile boundaries align with the artifacts.

status.summary: Video rotation metadata is not taken into account when playing back the video using webgl texImage2D

Kelsey.author: jgilbert@mozilla.com
Kelsey.text:
That sounds right.

**In the case where we get to BlitSdToFramebuffer, we should propagate a rotation matrix** to this point, so that exif-rotated videos still upload via gpu-copy instead of rotate-and-upload-from-cpu.

But **we will also need to support the rotate-and-upload-from-cpu** because that is the fallback, and we don't always hit BlitSdToFramebuffer.

status.summary: Page rendering artifacts on particular Shadertoy example (WR TDR behavior could be better)

JimB.author: jimb@mozilla.com
JimB.text: This looks like the WebGL usage is somehow impacting other parts of Firefox's rendering, so I think this is pretty serious.

JimB.author: ahale@mozilla.com
JimB.text: I'll attempt repro on my nvidia windows 10 system and see if I can characterize this more exactly.

JimB.author: gwatson@mozilla.com
JimB.text: Could you try enable `gfx.webrender.debug.picture-caching` in `about:config`, and capture a screenshot with that enabled when the artifacts occur? It would be interesting to see if the picture cache tile boundaries align with the artifacts.

JimB.author: jgilbert@mozilla.com
JimB.text: This is probably webgl causing a TDR (~timed-out device reset) where the webrender context resets in the middle of a wr rendering, but with default GL state, and so starts drawing into FB0 and such things. Not great but not terrible. No real path to exploit, but it'd be nice for WR to be better-behaved in this case.

I can't repro this on the following computers:
* Ryzen 7 5800X + Geforce RTX 3080 Ti
  * Windows 11
  * Windows 10 (same machine, dual boot for testing)
* Ryzen 9 7950X3D + Radeon RX 7900 XTX on Windows 11
* Dell laptop with Core i9-11900H
  * using Intel UHD Graphics on Windows 11
  * NVIDIA RTX 3050 Ti Laptop GPU on Windows 11 (same machine, device enabled and graphics preference set to high performance for Firefox.exe)
* MSI gaming laptop with Core i7-8750H CPU
  * using Intel UHD Graphics 630 on Windows 11
  * using RTX 2060 Ti laptop GPU (this model is approximately desktop equivalent unlike most laptop GPUs, )

In all cases the display is stable, no artifacting outside the shadertoy view, fans run loudly though on all of these.

I tried with and without vsync on a few of these configurations.

I agree with Kelsey's assessment that this is a TDR, and hence a hardware problem (most commonly either thermal or power related, can be a problem just with that board too).
JimB.author: ahale@mozilla.com

status.summary: Support PNG and/or “short” BI_BITFIELDS DIBv5 when pasting images (pixel data shifted when copy/pasting from Paint.NET)

Ashley.text: This is fascinating, and very relevant to my work on fixing the clipboard handling in https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=460969, thank you for the information :)
Ashley.author: ahale@mozilla.com
mercury13@ukr.net
Ashley.text:
Ashley Hale [:ahale]
Thank you.
UPD. IDK how to copy data in alternate formats, and need as simple example as possible, so I didn’t test PNG. I just tested three standard formats, BITMAP, DIB and  DIBv5. Did not even test transparency for now.

Ashley.author: mercury13@ukr.net
Ashley.text:
Ashley, you made me check COPYING transparent images, lady.

Translucent DIBv5 short ONLY:
* Totally OK: Paint.NET, Vivaldi
* Shifted pixel data: Fx, XnView
* No transparency: some old Photoshop, GIMP

(Let me skip DIBv5 long, as it won’t make any difference)

Translucent DIB ONLY:
* OK: Paint.NET, Fx, Vivaldi
* No transparency: XnView, Photoshop, GIMP

Translucent BITMAP ONLY:
* OK: Paint.NET
* No transparency: Fx, Photoshop
* No transparency, strange pixel data troubles: Vivaldi, GIMP

Probably Windows works by converting BITMAP → long DIBv5 → buggy DIB (both Vivaldi and GIMP prefer DIB).

How other image editors work here:
Photoshop: creates lot of formats, no one understands except Photoshop itself
GIMP: creates PNG + BI_RGB DIB/long DIBv5 w/transparency, understood by Paint.NET and Vivaldi
Paint.NET: creates PNG + BI_BITFIELDS DIB/short DIBv5, understood by everyone except Photoshop (Fx/XnView make artifacts, as always)
XnView: creates correct but premultiplied images, don’t even bother to support (Paint.NET managed to bother)

What and in which order should you COPY to avoid most bugs?
ALL FOUR FORMATS in any order: PNG, BITMAP, DIB, DIBv5
But that’s copying, not pasting. When pasting, it’s better to understand PNG and/or short DIBv5.
GIMP: I said long DIBv5? As it’s BI_RGB, there’s no difference between long and short.
Ashley.author: mercury13@ukr.net

Erich.author: tnikkel@gmail.com
Erich.text:
(In reply to Erich Gubler [:ErichDonGubler] from comment #6)
> Mayank, I doubt the specific revision you mentioned is the culprit (because it only changes test expectations in CI, and does not actually change Firefox), but I believe other patches in the stack filed against [bug 1841050](https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1841050) could very well be the culprit.

That's a problem with mozregression, it seems to pick the last changeset when it can only narrow it down to a set of changesets (because there were multiple changesets in the push).
Is it possible to provide a more reduced testcase?
Erich.author: tnikkel@gmail.com
tnikkel@gmail.com
Erich.text:
(In reply to Erich Gubler [:ErichDonGubler] from comment #6)
> Does setting `webgl.gl_khr_no_error` fix this issue?

Yes it does.
Testing on macos, setting webgl.gl_khr_no_error to the same value as Windows does not reproduce the bug. So maybe it's something related to angle.
Erich.author: tnikkel@gmail.com

Erich.text:
Testing on Windows or mac when webgl.gl_khr_no_error=true in a debug build we actually hit a fatal assert.

[gl:0x14bb7f100] void mozilla::gl::GLContext::raw_fBlitFramebuffer(GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLbitfield, GLenum): Generated unexpected GL_INVALID_OPERATION error.
Crash Annotation GraphicsCriticalError: |[0][GFX1]: void mozilla::gl::GLContext::raw_fBlitFramebuffer(GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLbitfield, GLenum): Generated unexpected GL_INVALID_OPERATION error (t=17.6361) [GFX1]: void mozilla::gl::GLContext::raw_fBlitFramebuffer(GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLint, GLbitfield, GLenum): Generated unexpected GL_INVALID_OPERATION error
 
We are passing
0 0 2560 1508 0 0 2560 1508 16384 9728
to BlitFramebuffer so
mask=16384=0x4000=LOCAL_GL_COLOR_BUFFER_BIT
filter=9728=0x2600=LOCAL_GL_NEAREST

https://registry.khronos.org/OpenGL-Refpages/gl4/html/glBlitFramebuffer.xhtml gives reasons why we might get GL_INVALID_OPERATION with a glBlitFramebuffer call. So perhaps the testcase could be doing something not quite correct?

I agree with Kelsey's assessment that this is a TDR, and hence a hardware problem (most commonly either thermal or power related, can be a problem just with that board too).
JimB.author: ahale@mozilla.com

Glenn.author: gwatson@mozilla.com
Glenn.text: Could you try enable `gfx.webrender.debug.picture-caching` in `about:config`, and capture a screenshot with that enabled when the artifacts occur? It would be interesting to see if the picture cache tile boundaries align with the artifacts.

Glenn.author: jgilbert@mozilla.com
Glenn.text: This is probably webgl causing a TDR (~timed-out device reset) where the webrender context resets in the middle of a wr rendering, but with default GL state, and so starts drawing into FB0 and such things. Not great but not terrible. No real path to exploit, but it'd be nice for WR to be better-behaved in this case.

I can't repro this on the following computers:
* Ryzen 7 5800X + Geforce RTX 3080 Ti
  * Windows 11
  * Windows 10 (same machine, dual boot for testing)
* Ryzen 9 7950X3D + Radeon RX 7900 XTX on Windows 11
* Dell laptop with Core i9-11900H
  * using Intel UHD Graphics on Windows 11
  * NVIDIA RTX 3050 Ti Laptop GPU on Windows 11 (same machine, device enabled and graphics preference set to high performance for Firefox.exe)
* MSI gaming laptop with Core i7-8750H CPU
  * using Intel UHD Graphics 630 on Windows 11
  * using RTX 2060 Ti laptop GPU (this model is approximately desktop equivalent unlike most laptop GPUs, )

In all cases the display is stable, no artifacting outside the shadertoy view, fans run loudly though on all of these.

I tried with and without vsync on a few of these configurations.

I agree with Kelsey's assessment that this is a TDR, and hence a hardware problem (most commonly either thermal or power related, can be a problem just with that board too).
Glenn.author: ahale@mozilla.com

status.summary: Vertex pulling on Metal

JimB.text:
It seems like the "Note:" at the end of the [definition of `drawIndexed`](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#dom-gpurendercommandsmixin-drawindexed) gives us some alternatives:

> Note: a valid program should also never use vertex indices with [GPUVertexStepMode."vertex"](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/#dom-gpuvertexstepmode-vertex) that are out of bounds. WebGPU implementations have different ways of handling this, and therefore a range of behaviors is allowed. Either the whole draw call is discarded, or the access to those attributes out of bounds is described by WGSL’s [invalid memory reference](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/wgsl/#invalid-memory-reference).

That last clause there about treating it like an "invalid memory reference" means that we have the same options as for dealing with out-of-bounds array indices in WGSL. This includes returning zeros, or returning data from elsewhere in the array.

I think tossing the entire draw call would be a little hard to implement. There isn't any way that I'm aware of for a vertex shader to cancel the draw call. Producing a [zero value](https://gpuweb.github.io/gpuweb/wgsl/#zero-value-builtin-function) might be the easiest for users to debug.



 we can toss the entire draw call, or just provide random data to the shader.

The latter would permit implementations that simply clamp the vertex index to fall within bounds, returning either the first or the last element from the vertex buffer.

status.summary: [spv-out] decorate non-uniform image/sampler access chains

Teo.text:
> The code looks like it has always been decorating the results of `OpAccessChain`, just not for binding arrays in the `Handle` address space.

The code originally decorated all access chains, https://github.com/gfx-rs/wgpu/commit/c3e35df576af8cdd345875b8af1ab541c43defd7 changed it so that it only happened for storage and uniform buffers since I thought that decorating the image/sampler access chains was not necessary. We now know this was necessary and is what this PR is reverting.

> The discussion suggests that both the pointer and the result of the load need to be decorated, but we are not decorating the result of the load / sample at all, as far as I can see.

Since https://github.com/gfx-rs/wgpu/commit/c3e35df576af8cdd345875b8af1ab541c43defd7 we decorate the load result of image/sampler binding arrays (the load result being an image/sampler); this is part of the VUID requirement.

The results of texture load/sampling operations don't have to be decorated.
Teo.author: teoxoy

Teo.text:

https://github.com/gfx-rs/wgpu/blob/418493239a8b24163587a027bcf4a00da25f91fb/wgpu-core/src/device/resource.rs#L3207-L3215

If you could figure out why Windows and Vulkan are failing that would be great.

Teo.text:
So it look like for the GL and DX12 backends `downlevel` is `true`, causing it to use `get_texture_format_features` and thus bypassing the checks that I added in `guaranteed_format_features` 😄 

If I add checks here (in the code you referred to) all tests pass on my Windows machine. Does this mean it makes more sense to just apply the checks here instead? Or do we still need them in `sample_type()`?
Teo.author: almarklein

Teo.text:
> Does this mean it makes more sense to just apply the checks here instead? Or do we still need them in sample_type()?

In retrospect I don't think it makes sense. Instead I made the `device_features` arg optional, so the code that provides the `Features::empty()` can pass `None` instead, which feels less awkward.

CI is green!
